claims_to_validate.claim_text: The system shows different daily wage calculation methods between leave policy and payroll settings. The payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence and overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave deductions. The greyed-out display in leave policy indicates an intentional override is in effect.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amount.

The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. When calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity, the system fails to recognize 2024 as a leap year, causing a calculation discrepancy of approximately AED 17.26.

Daily wage calculation for pro-rated amounts consistently produces slightly lower amounts due to decimal precision errors. When calculating End of Service (EOS) amounts, the system shows amounts less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.
System gratuity calculation showed slight difference from manual calculations (Bayzat: AED 231,821.10 vs Manual: AED 252,485)

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), potentially causing minor differences in total service days and resulting gratuity amount. The system calculated 912 days, while manual calculation suggested 913 days by including the leap day.

The system's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The calculation differs from manual expectations by using precise day counting and leap year adjustments (dividing by 366 for leap years).

Platform calculates total job tenure with a potential extra day (623 days vs expected 622 days), causing slight variations in gratuity calculations. The system uses a fixed 30-day divisor for daily wage, which differs from client's preferred (Basic × 12 / 365) calculation method.

System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. The daily wage divisor is fixed according to policy settings, potentially causing perceived calculation discrepancies.

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation mismatches. The client expects a consistent daily wage formula of (Basic salary + allowances / 30.42 days), but the system uses separate configurations.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The daily wage calculator fails to correctly prorate salary when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. The system only correctly prorates salaries when departure dates are in the past.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, there is a data synchronization issue between Time Off and Payroll modules. This causes mismatches in daily wage calculations, resulting in incorrect salary deductions that cannot be retroactively corrected.
The system displays incorrect daily rate remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. Employees are experiencing salary deductions calculated using gross salary instead of basic salary as configured in the leave policy.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is from the wrong month.
The current system cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking.
